posts.name: DrewTheRat
posts.cooked:
We have observed back current when we move our robot’s arm manually with power off. We can see LEDs on the radio light briefly, among other things. The motor is a NEO, and we want to disconnect it from the SPARK Max to prevent damage when we move the arm.

Does anyone know if disconnecting the black lead is enough, or do we need to disconnect two of the three leads to be safe?

posts.name: ToddF
posts.cooked:
The short answer is that this has been an observed phenomena for years with FRC motors and motor drivers.  I’m not aware of any instance where backdriving one of our mechanisms has resulted in damage to the electronics.  It’s totally freaky to be pushing your robot for a hundred yards with the LEDs on the electronics flashing like Christmas lights from the generated electricity.  But, everything always seems to work OK when you power up the robot.

So, if you feel you must, go ahead and unplug, but it’s not something we worry about anymore.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: What makes you believe that this is a problem?

posts.name: DrewTheRat
posts.cooked:
In general we don’t, but on mechanisms with a high gear ratio (e.g. 125:1 for our arm), we have had the motor controller fail. At our last event, we needed to replace the Spark MAX that drives the arm.

The location of the motor and controller are such that we need to extend the motor wires to make it easy to disconnect. I am wondering we can just disconnect the black lead, as it would be easier to just extend that wire.

posts.name: ToddF
posts.cooked:
DrewTheRat:

on mechanisms with a high gear ratio (e.g. 125:1 for our arm), we have had the motor controller fail

That’s wild.  I wonder if other teams have had similar experiences.  I’d say to just insert a toggle switch in the circuit, but that’s probably not legal, so you need to unplug.

If the motor was a brushed motor, unplugging just one of the wires would interrupt the circuit and prevent current from flowing.  With a 3 phase brushless motor the color coding is somewhat arbitrary.  The black and red wires aren’t continuously power and ground.  To completely prevent back current flow, you will need to disconnect two of the 3 wires.  If you are using a 3 position power pole connector (as you should be) it’s easier to just disconnect the block of 3 conductors.

image 748×342 47.2 KB

image 748×342 47.2 KB

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: Probably need to disconnect 2 leads. I’d find a 3 wire connector that is easy to plug and unplug, we used to use MT60s for all our neos and those would work well. That said as long as you don’t need the motor unplugged to be able move the arm I wouldn’t unplug it. Spark maxes don’t mind the back emf and you can forget to plug the motor back in (ask me how I know).

posts.name: Dominick Ferone
posts.cooked:
ToddF:

. It’s totally freaky to be pushing your robot for a hundred yards with the LEDs on the electronics flashing like Christmas lights from the generated electricity. But, everything always seems to work OK when you power up the robot.

Lesson learned many years ago. Pushing a robot back from the gym and pushing too quickly may have smoked the spike/victors.

Always throw the bot on a cart and make life easier.

posts.name: Nyx
posts.cooked: Not an electronics whiz, but might diodes work?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Everything and nothing, all at the same time

posts.custom_user_title: Everything and nothing, all at the same time

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked: Diodes would interfere with proper operation of the motor+controller, and aren’t permitted by R625 anyway.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked:
Dominick_Ferone:

Lesson learned many years ago. Pushing a robot back from the gym and pushing too quickly may have smoked the spike/victors.

Victors are considerable more fragile. Spike are relays powered of a 5V supply going through the Rio’s FPGA. No amount of pushing would damage them

posts.name: Levi
posts.cooked: We blew out a rev blinkin this way in 2022
